G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, a custody order may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and when modification is necessary in the child’s best interest.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Now comes the Plaintiff, **Samantha Greene**, pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, **G.L. c. 209C, § 20**, and the inherent equity powers of this Honorable Court, and respectfully petitions for a *Complaint for Modification* of the existing custody judgment entered by this Court on **May 15, 2018**, regarding the parties’ minor child, **Emily Greene (age 12)**.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The Plaintiff states that a substantial and material change in circumstances has arisen since entry of the prior judgment such that modification of the current custody arrangement is necessary to protect and serve the *best interests of the child*, as required by **G.L. c. 208, § 31** and established caselaw.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting-time matters pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 & 31**, and **G.L. c. 215, § 6**, as the underlying Order was entered in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31A.proposition: The Court is also guided by **G.L. c. 208, § 31A** (abuse or safety considerations in custody determinations).

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: The Court is guided by the principle that *the best interests of the child* are the paramount concern.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in removal cases, although the court considers the custodial parent’s interests, the best interests of the children remain the “paramount concern.” The court then interprets the removal statute’s “upon cause shown” language to mean that removal must be in the best interests of the child and frames the entire analysis around that standard. Thus, the case clearly supports the proposition that the best interests of the child guide and control the court’s decision-making.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt:
“As most recently reformulated by the Supreme Court of New Jersey in Cooper v. Cooper, 99 N.J. 42 (1984), the ‘real advantage’ test is grounded on the ‘realization that after a divorce a child’s subsequent relationship with both parents can never be the same as before the divorce . . . [and] that the child’s quality of life and style of life are provided by the custodial parent.’ Id. at 53. Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…

…The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child….”}

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The Court is guided by the principle that *the best interests of the child* are the paramount concern.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that under G.L. c. 208, § 30, removal may be ordered only if it is in the children’s best interests, and repeatedly frames the analysis and review standard in terms of the “best interests of the children.” The court affirms the probate judge’s decision by evaluating whether the removal would serve the children’s best interests, demonstrating that this standard is the paramount concern guiding the court’s decision in this context.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that… [a child] shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.… ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: A parent seeking modification must demonstrate that the earlier judgment’s underlying circumstances have materially changed.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the governing standard for modification of alimony or child support: the petitioner must show a material change of circumstances since entry of the prior judgment. The court then applies that standard and affirms because the husband failed to prove the requisite change. This directly matches the claimed proposition.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). In this case, the judge held that Chester did not prove the requisite change of circumstances.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: A parent seeking modification must demonstrate that the earlier judgment’s underlying circumstances have materially changed.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion is a direct appeal from an initial custody judgment, focused on the need for explicit findings regarding domestic violence and its effect on the child. It does not discuss standards for a later modification of an existing custody order, nor does it state that a parent seeking modification must prove a material change in circumstances. The proposition concerns modification doctrine, which this case does not address.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that serious health or medical developments constituting a safety concern for the child qualify as a substantial change.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses what qualifies as a material and substantial change in circumstances for custody modification, but it does so in the context of relocation and work/life changes, not serious health or medical developments or safety concerns. The court ultimately finds *no* material and substantial change in circumstances and nowhere states or implies that new health or medical safety issues constitute such a change. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition about health or medical developments qualifying as a substantial change.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ Fuller v. Fuller, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 372, 376 (1974). ‘The uprooting of a child . . . should be done only for compelling reasons.’”

E.N.O. v. L.M.M., 429 Mass. 824 (1999).proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that serious health or medical developments constituting a safety concern for the child qualify as a substantial change.
E.N.O. v. L.M.M., 429 Mass. 824 (1999).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a de facto parent may be granted visitation based on the Probate Court’s equity jurisdiction and the child’s best interests. It does not discuss modification standards, substantial change in circumstances, or health/medical developments as a basis for changing an existing order. There is only a passing reference to the defendant’s medical problems as background, not as a legal ground for modification, so the case does not support the claimed proposition about serious health developments qualifying as a substantial change.
E.N.O. v. L.M.M., 429 Mass. 824 (1999).relevant_excerpt: “After the child was born, the plaintiff assumed most of the financial responsibility for the family. Later, for a period of approximately seven months, the plaintiff also assumed primary care for the child because the defendant was experiencing medical problems.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: In evaluating custody, courts consider the child’s welfare, stability, and emotional security.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely applies the “best interests of the child” standard and explicitly emphasizes welfare, stability, and continuity as central considerations in custody determinations. The court discusses the child’s welfare in terms of medical, educational, and daily needs, and stresses that maintaining stable, continuous living arrangements and relationships with caregivers is itself a major component of the child’s best interests and emotional well-being. Thus it clearly supports the proposition that courts consider the child’s welfare, stability, and emotional security in evaluating custody.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt:
“If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

“…the mother is more ‘attuned’ to Kali’s medical, educational, and daily needs and is better able to provide for Kali’s welfare and physical needs during the week….”

Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.raw_text: Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981)
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.proposition: Massachusetts law permits modification where continuation of an existing plan would impose inappropriate responsibilities upon a minor child.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.support_reasoning: The case addresses modification/removal standards in terms of the best interests of the child and the intertwined welfare of the custodial parent, but it does not discuss modification based on ‘inappropriate responsibilities upon a minor child.’ The court focuses on relocation, visitation patterns, and the custodial parent’s well-being, not on relieving a child of inappropriate burdens. Thus, it does not squarely support the specific proposition stated.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that while the trial judge considered one important factor, the children’s need for weekly visitation by the noncustodial parent, we cannot ascertain whether he also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests. More particularly, it does not appear that he considered the advantages of the move with respect to the emotional well-being of the family unit as a whole, or the emotional costs of forcing a stressful family and career choice…on the parent having the primary responsibility for the day-to-day care of the children.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Massachusetts law permits modification where continuation of an existing plan would impose inappropriate responsibilities upon a minor child.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion does not address modification of an existing parenting or custody plan at all, nor does it discuss limitations based on inappropriate responsibilities being placed on a minor child. Rolde concerns an initial divorce judgment involving division of marital property, custody (joint vs. sole), and visitation, analyzed under the best-interests standard. There is no language about post-judgment modification or about changing an arrangement because it would impose inappropriate responsibilities on a minor, so it does not support the claimed proposition.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge concluded that ‘joint custody or shared responsibility is an invitation to continued warfare and conflict.’ … Although the husband had had involvement with the child rearing functions and responsibilities, the judge concluded that because the parties have basic fundamental differences… an order providing joint custody would run contrary to the children’s happiness and welfare.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: The Plaintiff’s request does not seek to sever the child’s relationship with her father but to ensure that Emily’s safety, developmental needs, and emotional stability remain prioritized during the father’s medical decline, fully consistent with **Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998)** and **Care & Protection of Robert, 408 Mass. 52 (1990)**.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The proposition characterizes Hugo as authority that a court may prioritize a child’s safety, developmental needs, and emotional stability during a caregiver’s difficulties without severing the parental relationship. Hugo, however, is a care-and-protection/adoption case about choosing between two nonparent adoptive placements after both parents have been found unfit and their consent dispensed with. The opinion does not address maintaining or structuring an ongoing relationship with a biological parent during that parent’s medical decline; rather, it focuses on best-interests analysis between competing adoptive caretakers, including the willingness to change placements despite existing bonds. Thus it does not support the specific use stated in the proposition.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’ … Here the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development.”

Care & Protection of Robert, 408 Mass. 5.proposition: The Plaintiff’s request does not seek to sever the child’s relationship with her father but to ensure that Emily’s safety, developmental needs, and emotional stability remain prioritized during the father’s medical decline, fully consistent with **Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998)** and **Care & Protection of Robert, 408 Mass. 52 (1990)**.
Care & Protection of Robert, 408 Mass. 5.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns prioritizing a child’s safety, developmental needs, and emotional stability during a parent’s medical decline without severing the parent‑child relationship. Care & Protection of Robert deals instead with the constitutional standard of proof at a 72‑hour care and protection hearing and the balance between parental rights, child safety, and the State’s interests. While the opinion generally recognizes the State’s parens patriae role and a child’s interest in safety versus family integrity, it does not address medical decline of a parent, nor does it frame relief in terms of preserving the relationship while managing such decline, so it does not specifically support the stated proposition.
Care & Protection of Robert, 408 Mass. 5.relevant_excerpt: “The State as parens patriae may act to protect minor children from serious physical or emotional harm. In some instances this may require a partial or complete severance of the parent-child relationship… A child’s interest in the integrity of his or her family, much like the equivalent interest of the parent, is not absolute… The child’s interest in freedom from abusive or neglectful behavior, however, is absolute.”
